title: China sends 11th medical team to Papua New Guinea in 2021
description: On March 9, 2021, the 11th Chinese medical aid team to Papua New Guinea departed from Chongqing to take over the duties of the 10th team. It will provide medical aid at Port Moresby General Hospital in the country's capital for one year. The 10-member team, with an average age of 39, includes eight medical workers, a translator and a cook. 8 of them returned on August 10th, 2022, after 16 months, while 2 of them stayed.  Besides doing routine clinical work, the team will bring advanced domestic clinical diagnosis and treatment technology to PNG, help fight COVID-19 and provide medical services for overseas Chinese residents. Their expertise covers urology, obstetrics and gynecology, cardiovascular medicine, oncology, neurosurgery and neonatology.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China sends 11th medical team to Papua New Guinea in 2021

# Description
On March 9, 2021, the 11th Chinese medical aid team to Papua New Guinea departed from Chongqing to take over the duties of the 10th team. It will provide medical aid at Port Moresby General Hospital in the country's capital for one year. The 10-member team, with an average age of 39, includes eight medical workers, a translator and a cook. 8 of them returned on August 10th, 2022, after 16 months, while 2 of them stayed.  Besides doing routine clinical work, the team will bring advanced domestic clinical diagnosis and treatment technology to PNG, help fight COVID-19 and provide medical services for overseas Chinese residents. Their expertise covers urology, obstetrics and gynecology, cardiovascular medicine, oncology, neurosurgery and neonatology.
justification: Project is focused on providing medical aid and services, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team providing clinical work, COVID-19 support, and medical services in Papua New Guinea

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Papua New Guinea in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Papua New Guinea signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $27,333,000 ($18,345,000 in principal payments and $8,989,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’; (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Papua New Guinea. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Papua New Guinea secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Papua New Guinea in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Papua New Guinea signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $27,333,000 ($18,345,000 in principal payments and $8,989,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’; (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, focus on financial restructuring and COVID-19 response

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 499 million government concessional loan for Digital TV Transformation Project
description: On November 8, 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Papua New Guinea signed an RMB 499 million government concessional loan agreement for the Digital TV Transformation Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower is expected to use the proceeds of the GCL to finance 100% of the cost of an RMB 499 million ($69.28 million) commercial contract between China State Construction Engineering Corporation PNG Limited and the National Broadcasting Corporation (NBC) of Papua New Guinea, which was signed on March 27, 2020.   The purpose of this project is to fully upgrade PNG's existing analog signal TV system, and transform it into an ‘end-to-end’ digital TV system covering its major cities in 10 provinces with a full-link system that starts from program production and ends with user viewing. It will seek to provide high-quality digital TV services for local people, consolidate the foundation of digital information construction in PNG, and accelerate the pace of modernization and application of digital technology. The project will also involve establishing the main NBC transmission station 25 kilowatt to power the MW transmission signal in the country and it will be stationed in Lae, Morobe Province. China State Construction Engineering Corporation PNG Limited is the contractor responsible for implementation.   Project implementation commenced in June 2022. The project was originally expected to reach completion within 18 months.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Analogue to Digital Migration Project. The Chinese project title is 巴布亚新几内亚数字电视改造项目 or 巴布亚新几内亚数字电视项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 499 million government concessional loan for Digital TV Transformation Project

# Description
On November 8, 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Papua New Guinea signed an RMB 499 million government concessional loan agreement for the Digital TV Transformation Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower is expected to use the proceeds of the GCL to finance 100% of the cost of an RMB 499 million ($69.28 million) commercial contract between China State Construction Engineering Corporation PNG Limited and the National Broadcasting Corporation (NBC) of Papua New Guinea, which was signed on March 27, 2020.   The purpose of this project is to fully upgrade PNG's existing analog signal TV system, and transform it into an ‘end-to-end’ digital TV system covering its major cities in 10 provinces with a full-link system that starts from program production and ends with user viewing. It will seek to provide high-quality digital TV services for local people, consolidate the foundation of digital information construction in PNG, and accelerate the pace of modernization and application of digital technology. The project will also involve establishing the main NBC transmission station 25 kilowatt to power the MW transmission signal in the country and it will be stationed in Lae, Morobe Province. China State Construction Engineering Corporation PNG Limited is the contractor responsible for implementation.   Project implementation commenced in June 2022. The project was originally expected to reach completion within 18 months.
justification: Project focuses on digital TV system upgrade without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Digital TV transformation, upgrading analog to digital system, focus on broadcasting infrastructure

title: Chinese Government donated anti-epidemic aid to Papua New Guinea East Highlands Province in November 2021
description: On November 9, 2021, Zeng Fanhua, Ambassador to Papua New Guinea, handed over anti-epidemic aid to Governor of Papua New Guinea East Highlands Province. The aid is for the PNG East Highlands Province. The ambassador from China expressed support for the strengthening of diplomatic relations between China and PNG and gratitude for PNG's aid for China at the beginning of the pandemic.
staff_comments: 1. Lowy Institute claims aid amounted to K280,000.00, but does not provide a source.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donated anti-epidemic aid to Papua New Guinea East Highlands Province in November 2021

# Description
On November 9, 2021, Zeng Fanhua, Ambassador to Papua New Guinea, handed over anti-epidemic aid to Governor of Papua New Guinea East Highlands Province. The aid is for the PNG East Highlands Province. The ambassador from China expressed support for the strengthening of diplomatic relations between China and PNG and gratitude for PNG's aid for China at the beginning of the pandemic.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and health support without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Anti-epidemic aid, health sector focus, diplomatic relations strengthening

title: Chinese Government donates medical supplies to Port Moresby General Hospital in June 2021
description: On June 21 2021, Chinese Ambassador Zeng Fanhua donated a batch of medical equipment to Port Moresby General Hospital in Papua New Guinea. The donation included ventilators and consumables.  At the handover ceremony, Ambassador Zeng announced that the Chinese government would be supporting a revitalization of the Taurama Military Hospital, also in Port Moresby.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates medical supplies to Port Moresby General Hospital in June 2021

# Description
On June 21 2021, Chinese Ambassador Zeng Fanhua donated a batch of medical equipment to Port Moresby General Hospital in Papua New Guinea. The donation included ventilators and consumables.  At the handover ceremony, Ambassador Zeng announced that the Chinese government would be supporting a revitalization of the Taurama Military Hospital, also in Port Moresby.
justification: Project involves donation of medical equipment and support for hospital revitalization, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical equipment donation, hospital revitalization support

title: Chinese Government provides scholarships for 25 Papua New Guinea students for 2022-23
description: On January 1 2021, the Chinese Government committed 25 full scholarships for Papua New Guinea students to study at a university in China from the academic year 2022/2023. The scholarship covers either a graduate/undergraduate degree or a master’s programs or doctoral program. The undergraduate program is fully conducted in the Chinese language, and both programs require a letter of recommendation from a "Parish Priest/Pastor/Church Elder."  This agreement is in accordance with the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Educational Cooperation between China and Papua New Guinea.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides scholarships for 25 Papua New Guinea students for 2022-23

# Description
On January 1 2021, the Chinese Government committed 25 full scholarships for Papua New Guinea students to study at a university in China from the academic year 2022/2023. The scholarship covers either a graduate/undergraduate degree or a master’s programs or doctoral program. The undergraduate program is fully conducted in the Chinese language, and both programs require a letter of recommendation from a "Parish Priest/Pastor/Church Elder."  This agreement is in accordance with the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Educational Cooperation between China and Papua New Guinea.
justification: Project focuses on education and human development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Scholarships for education, no energy or infrastructure components mentioned

title: Shenzen, China donates cultural and sport supplies to Butuka Academy, PNG in July 2021
description: On July 22 2021, the Chinese city of Shenzen donates cultural and sports supplies to Butuka Academy in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. The donation consisted of 3200 school bags and 100 soccer balls.  The Chinese Embassy in Papua New Guinea and Butuka Academy held a handover ceremony the donated goods donated by the Chinese city of Shenzhen. Ambassador Zeng Fanhua attended and delivered a speech. The Governor of Papua New Guinea Capital Administrative Region Parkop, the Chairman of the Board of Directors of Butuka Academy Ni Yumei, the Principal Tugu Nei and nearly 300 teachers and students attended the donation ceremony.  Shenzen, China and Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea are sister cities, and the Butuka Academy was founded with Chinese assistance.
combined_text:

The Chinese Embassy in Papua New Guinea and Butuka Academy held a handover ceremony the donated goods donated by the Chinese city of Shenzhen. Ambassador Zeng Fanhua attended and delivered a speech. The Governor of Papua New Guinea Capital Administrative Region Parkop, the Chairman of the Board of Directors of Butuka Academy Ni Yumei, the Principal Tugu Nei and nearly 300 teachers and students attended the donation ceremony.  Shenzen, China and Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea are sister cities, and the Butuka Academy was founded with Chinese assistance.
justification: Project involves donation of educational and sports supplies without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of school bags and soccer balls, educational focus, no energy-related components

title: China donates personal protective equipment to Port Moresby General Hospital in October 2021
description: On Friday October 15 2021, China donated personal protective equipment (PPE) to Port Moresby General Hospital in Papua New Guinea. The donation included 10,000 surgical masks and gloves, 5,000 hospital gowns, and hand sanitizer.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates personal protective equipment to Port Moresby General Hospital in October 2021

# Description
On Friday October 15 2021, China donated personal protective equipment (PPE) to Port Moresby General Hospital in Papua New Guinea. The donation included 10,000 surgical masks and gloves, 5,000 hospital gowns, and hand sanitizer.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of personal protective equipment to hospital, healthcare focus

title: China donates dental equipment worth K300,000 to East New Britain Health Authority in November 2021
description: On November 16, 2021, China donated dental equipment worth K300,000 to the East New Britain Health Authority in Papua New Guinea. Governor Nakikus Konga of East New Britain Province said the equipment would go to Nonga General Hospital.

title: Chinese Government donates 1 million Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $18 million in November 2021
description: In November 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 1 million donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Peru.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the November 2021 donation as $18 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 1 million Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $18 million in November 2021

# Description
In November 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 1 million donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Peru.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 1 million vaccine doses, healthcare focus
